Description: Using fixed-time bars on irregular tick data loses information and introduces aliasing
Do: Use continuous-time filters (Kalman, Leaky Integrator) that adapt to Δt between events
Don't: Force fixed time/volume bars, use standard EMA without time-weighting

Description: Time gaps contain information (intensity, regime changes)
Do: Weight by actual time elapsed: α = 1 - exp(-Δt/τ)
Don't: Use bar-index based counters, ignore time gaps in decay functions

Description: Excessive parameter tuning on historical data leads to strategy failure in live trading
Do: Use walk-forward analysis, out-of-sample testing, limit parameters (<5), cross-validation
Don't: Optimize 10+ parameters, test only in-sample, maximize historical Sharpe

Description: Using future data unknowingly in backtest (e.g., end-of-day indicators calculated with closing auction data)
Do: Ensure all signals use only data available at signal time, timestamp everything
Don't: Use 'close' prices before they're known, reindex data without checking timestamps

Description: Testing only on assets that survived (e.g., current S&P 500 components tested back to 1990)
Do: Use point-in-time universe data, include delisted/dead assets in backtest
Don't: Test on current asset list backfilled 10 years, ignore delistings

Description: Backtests assume perfect fills at mid-price; real execution incurs slippage and fees
Do: Model realistic slippage (0.02-0.1%), include exchange fees (0.01-0.1% per side)
Don't: Assume fills at bid/ask mid without slippage, ignore fees in backtest

Keywords: liquidity market-impact adv volume position-sizing order-size
Description: Large orders move the market; testing with unrealistic position sizes vs. available liquidity
Do: Limit position size to % of ADV (1-5%), model market impact, scale in/out
Don't: Size positions at 50% of daily volume, assume instant fills for large size

Description: Running strategies without stop-loss can lead to ruin on single bad trade
Do: Implement hard stops (ATR-based or fixed %), max drawdown limits, circuit breakers
Don't: Hope position recovers, hold through massive unrealized loss

Description: Using excessive leverage (e.g., 50x-100x) magnifies losses and leads to liquidation
Do: Use conservative leverage (2x-5x max for most), maintain margin buffer (50%+ above maintenance)
Don't: Use maximum exchange leverage (100x+), ignore margin requirements

Description: Holding positions that are highly correlated (e.g., all crypto, all tech stocks) without realizing concentration risk
Do: Monitor correlation matrix, diversify across uncorrelated assets (<0.5 correlation)
Don't: Assume assets are independent, concentrate 100% in single sector/asset class

Description: Using 'clean' data that removes outliers, errors, or has been adjusted post-hoc
Do: Use raw or minimally cleaned data, validate with multiple sources, include errors/gaps
Don't: Remove all 'bad' data points, backfill missing data with interpolation

Description: Stocks split/pay dividends; unadjusted prices create false signals
Do: Use adjusted prices for backtesting, track corporate actions, handle dividends correctly
Don't: Use raw unadjusted prices, ignore dividend ex-dates and splits

Description: Markets evolve; strategies optimized for 2015 may fail in 2025
Do: Test across multiple regimes, use adaptive parameters, monitor live performance for drift
Don't: Optimize once on 2015-2020 data, deploy unchanged in 2025

Description: Crypto/volatility has fat tails; Gaussian models (VaR, mean-variance) underestimate risk
Do: Use robust risk measures (CVaR, stress tests), expect >3σ moves, tail hedging
Don't: Rely solely on VaR at 95%, assume returns are normal, ignore outliers

Description: Using centered moving averages or indicators that 'look ahead' (e.g., center-weighted MA)
Do: Use causal indicators only (EMA, trailing MA), ensure real-time implementability
Don't: Use centered SMA (looks ahead N/2 bars), apply offline indicators in backtest

Description: Over-smoothing signals (e.g., 200-period MA) introduces lag and misses fast moves
Do: Balance smoothness vs. lag, test multiple periods, use adaptive filters if needed
Don't: Use 500-bar MA for day trading, smooth until signal is 'clean'

Description: Reporting only favorable metrics (e.g., 'max 1-day return') while hiding drawdowns
Do: Report full metrics: Sharpe, max DD, win rate, worst month, total return, Calmar
Don't: Show only best month, highest Sharpe in ideal period, ignore drawdowns

Description: Only looking at max drawdown % ignores how long it takes to recover
Do: Monitor drawdown duration, time underwater, psychological pain of long flat periods
Don't: Accept 40% drawdown if 'eventually recovered', ignore 2-year flat equity

Description: Calculating signals after execution, or using wrong timestamp sequence
Do: Process: 1) receive data, 2) calculate signal, 3) execute, 4) update state. Timestamp everything.
Don't: Execute first, calculate signal later; mix real-time and delayed data

Description: Common in lookback calculations (e.g., MA over last 10 bars uses [i-9:i] not [i-10:i])
Do: Carefully test boundary conditions, use inclusive/exclusive ranges correctly, unit test
Don't: Assume [0:10] includes index 10, loop from i=0 when i=1 is first valid

Description: Running live without comprehensive logs makes debugging impossible post-failure
Do: Log every signal, order, fill, state change with microsecond timestamps
Don't: Println to console only, no persistent logs, no order audit trail

Description: Algo runs amok (bug, flash crash, API error) with no way to stop it
Do: Implement manual kill switch, max daily loss limit, position limit breakers, algo health checks
Don't: Deploy with no halt mechanism, assume 'it will never happen'

Keywords: latency jitter network-delay timing edge race-condition
Description: Assuming consistent latency; network jitter can destroy HFT edge
Do: Monitor latency distribution (p50, p99), co-locate if needed, design for variance
Don't: Assume 10ms latency is always 10ms, ignore occasional 500ms spikes

Description: Strategies that cross the spread pay the cost; ignoring it overestimates profitability
Do: Calculate effective spread, model crossing cost, prefer passive orders when possible
Don't: Assume trades at mid-price, ignore spread in backtest

Description: Market makers face informed traders; filling against them loses money
Do: Monitor fill rates vs. subsequent price moves, avoid toxic flow, implement anti-gaming logic
Don't: Assume all fills are random, ignore post-fill price drift

Description: Feature engineering uses future information (e.g., normalizing with global mean including test set)
Do: Split data first, fit preprocessing only on train set, apply to test; strict temporal separation
Don't: Normalize entire dataset first, then split; use test set statistics in training

Description: ML models degrade as market evolves; 2020 model fails in 2024
Do: Schedule regular retraining (weekly, monthly), monitor live performance, detect drift
Don't: Train once in 2020, deploy forever, ignore performance decay

Description: Using 1000 features on 500 samples guarantees overfitting
Do: Use feature selection (L1 regularization, PCA, domain knowledge), keep feature count << sample count
Don't: Generate every possible technical indicator (500 features), train on 1 year of daily data

Keywords: revenge-trading tilt emotional-trading discipline psychology loss-chasing
Description: After loss, abandoning risk rules to 'make it back' by over-leveraging or overtrading
Do: Stick to risk limits after loss, take break if tilted, automate execution to remove emotion
Don't: Double position size after loss, trade without stop, take high-risk setups

Keywords: drawdown abandonment system-hopping strategy-switching patience discipline
Description: Stopping live strategy during drawdown period, missing eventual recovery
Do: Trust backtested edge, allow for normal drawdown, only stop if system is fundamentally broken
Don't: Stop trading after 15% DD even though backtest showed 25% max DD is normal
